Pre‑clinical (laboratory & animal) stage | Activity | What was done | Safety signals looked for | |----------|---------------|---------------------------| | **Antigen production** | Each component (e.g., diphtheria toxoid, pertussis proteins, inactivated poliovirus, Hib polysaccharide‑protein conjugate) was produced in separate manufacturing lines, purified, and then mixed under sterile conditions. | • Purity (absence of contaminating bacterial DNA, endotoxin).

## 1. What “post‑licensure monitoring” (sometimes called **Phase IV surveillance**) actually looks like When a vaccine is approved, regulators are **not finished** with safety work. The goal now is to watch *billions* of real‑world doses for signals that are **too rare, delayed, or population‑specific** to have been seen in the pre‑licensure trials (which usually involve ≤ 30 000 participants). Below is a “road‑map” of the major surveillance components used in the United States and in many other high‑income countries. (Low‑ and middle‑income countries add similar layers, often coordinated through the WHO Global Vaccine Safety Initiative.) | **System** | **How it works** | **Strengths** | **Limitations** | |------------|------------------|---------------|-----------------| | **Passive reporting** (e.g., **VAERS** in the U.S., **Yellow Card** in the U.K., **EudraVigilance** in the EU) | Anyone—health‑care providers, parents, vaccine manufacturers—can submit a report of an event that occurs after vaccination. Reports are stored in a national database and are searchable by vaccine, age, timing, etc. | • Very broad coverage (captures events that would never be seen in formal studies).
• Low cost, quick to set up for a new vaccine. | • Under‑reporting (most mild events never get reported).
• Reporting bias (high media attention can inflate reports).
• No denominator (you don’t know how many doses were given). | | **Active surveillance networks** (e.g., **Vaccine Safety Datalink – VSD**, **CDC’s Immunization Safety Office’s** rapid cycle analyses, **FDA’s Sentinel System**) | Large health‑care organizations (Kaiser, Harvard Pilgrim, etc.) share de‑identified electronic health‑record data. Researchers can **compare rates** of a specific outcome in vaccinated vs. matched unvaccinated (or differently‑vaccinated) children, adjusting for age, geography, comorbidities. | • Provides a *numerator* (cases) **and** a *denominator* (total doses).
• Can detect **rare events** (1‑10 per 100 000) and **time‑limited signals** (e.g., within 7 days of vaccination).
• Allows rapid “near‑real‑time” analyses (often within weeks of a safety concern). | • Limited to the populations that belong to participating health‑systems (may under‑represent rural or uninsured groups).
• Requires sophisticated statistical methods to control for confounding. | | **Post‑licensure clinical studies** (Phase IV trials, cohort studies, pregnancy registries) | Researchers design a specific study to answer a safety question (e.g., “Does the new COVID‑19 vaccine increase the risk of febrile seizures in infants?”). | • Can collect **detailed exposure data** (dose, lot number) and **pre‑specified outcomes** (neurologic exams, lab tests).
• Provides higher causal inference than passive reports. | • Takes months‑to‑years to enroll enough participants for very rare outcomes. | | **International safety monitoring** (WHO’s **Global Advisory Committee on Vaccine Safety – GACVS**, **Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System – VAERS** data shared globally, **Vaccine Safety Net**) | Countries pool data, harmonise case definitions (e.g., Brighton Collaboration standards), and jointly investigate signals that appear in more than one region. | • Increases statistical power for ultra‑rare events (e.g., 1 per million).
• Detects **geographically specific problems** (e.g., a lot‑specific contamination). | • Requires data‑sharing agreements, standardisation of coding, and time for cross‑border analyses. | | **Lot‑release testing & pharmaco‑vigilance** | Every vaccine lot
